docs.title: Statistical Process Control (SPC)
docs.text: Statistical Process Control (SPC) is a systematic methodology rooted in statistical theory, designed to monitor, analyze, and enhance processes to ensure consistent and high-quality outcomes. It is a crucial aspect of quality management and process optimization across various industries, leveraging statistical techniques to discern process behaviors and variations.

docs.title: Control Charts
docs.text:
Control charts are pivotal tools in SPC, used to visualize and analyze process data over time. They allow for the real-time monitoring of process performance and the identification of variations that may indicate potential issues. There are different types of control charts, each tailored to specific aspects of process behavior:

  • X-bar Charts: Focus on the central tendency of a process by tracking the average values of samples. These charts help in detecting shifts or trends in the process mean, which may suggest changes in process performance or stability.

  • R Charts: Measure the dispersion or variability within the process by observing the range of sample data. They are instrumental in identifying changes in the spread of the process, which can indicate variability beyond normal expectations.

docs.title: Process Capability Indices
docs.text:
Process capability indices are metrics used to evaluate how well a process meets its specification limits. They provide insights into the ability of a process to produce outputs within desired quality standards:

  • Cp (Process Capability Index): Assesses the potential capability of a process based on the spread of the process data relative to the specification limits, assuming that the process is centered. It reflects the inherent ability of the process to produce outputs within the specified range.

  • Cpk (Process Capability Index, Adjusted for Centering): Evaluates the process capability by considering the process mean's deviation from the target. It provides a measure of how well the process is centered between the specification limits, offering a more comprehensive view of the process's performance.

docs.title: Variation Types
docs.text:
The distinction between different types of variation is essential in SPC:

  • Common Cause Variation: This type of variation is intrinsic to the process and is characterized by its stability and predictability over time. It reflects the natural and inherent variability present in a well-controlled process.

  • Special Cause Variation: This variation is attributable to specific, identifiable factors that are not part of the routine process operations. It signifies that the process may be experiencing atypical disturbances, which often necessitate corrective actions to restore process stability.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: SPC utilizes statistical methods to monitor and control processes, providing valuable insights into process behavior and performance. Through the use of control charts and process capability indices, SPC helps in distinguishing between different types of variation, guiding improvements, and maintaining quality standards within a process.

docs.title: 1. Arithemetic Mean
docs.text:
The arithmetic mean, often referred to as the average, is a measure of central tendency that is calculated by adding up all the numbers in a data set and then dividing by the number of observations.

Here x' = Arithmetic mean

xi = Individual value in the data set

N = Total number of values in the data set

docs.title: 2. Standard deviation
docs.text:
In statistics, the standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation of the values of a variable about its mean.

Here x = Arithmetic mean

n = Total number of values in the data set

σ = Standard Deviation

docs.title: 3. Range
docs.text:
A range refers to the difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset.

  • Minimum value = Smallest value in the Data set.

  • Maximum value = Largest value in the Data set.

docs.title: 4. Skewness
docs.text:
Skewness is a measure of symmetry in a distribution.

Here n = Total number of values in the data set

xi = Individual value in the data set

x' = Arithmetic mean

S = Standard deviation

If Skewness = 0 it indicates that the distribution of the data is perfectly symmetrical. If Skewness > 0 it indicates that the distribution of the data is positively skewed, also known as right-skewed. If Skewness < 0 it indicates that the distribution of the data is negatively skewed also known as left skewed.

docs.title: 5. Kurtosis
docs.text:
Kurtosis is the degree of peakedness of a distribution, usually taken relative to a normal distribution.

Here n = Total number of values in the data set

xi = individual value in the data set

x' = Arithmetic mean

S = Standard deviation

There are 3 cases for kurtosis:

  • When kurtosis is greater than 3, the distribution is called Leptokurtic. It has a sharper peak and fatter tails compared to a normal distribution, indicating a higher likelihood of extreme values.

  • When kurtosis is equal to 3, the distribution is called Mesokurtic. It has the same peak and tail behaviour as a normal distribution, meaning it has a moderate number of extreme values.

  • When kurtosis is lesser than 3, the distribution is called Platykurtic. It has a flatter peak and thinner tails compared to a normal distribution, indicating fewer extreme values.

docs.title: 6. Tolerance band
docs.text: A tolerance band is a range or interval within which a certain measurement, parameter, or value is allowed to vary without leading to a significant deviation from the desired or acceptable performance.

docs.title: 7. Potential Capability (Cp)
docs.text:
Cp is the ratio of the tolerance range (the difference between the upper and lower specification limits) to the process spread, which is typically measured as six standard deviations of the process.

Here 

(USL) Upper Specification limit = mean + 3(Standard deviation)

(LSL) Lower Specification Limit = mean -- 3(standard deviation)

σ = Standard deviation

docs.title: 8. Potential Capability (Cp)
docs.text:
Process capability is a statistical measure of a process's ability to produce output that meets specified limits or tolerances.

Here 

(USL) Upper Specification limit = mean + 3(Standard deviation)

(LSL) Lower Specification Limit = mean - 3(standard deviation)

σ = Standard deviation

x' = Arithmetic mean

docs.title: 9. Rejected parts
docs.text:
The values fall outside the range of tolerance band, so they would be considered out of specification.

Rejected parts = (x<lower tolerance) or (x> upper tolerance)

Here x = individual value in the data set

docs.title: 10. % of Total Reject
docs.text:
The percentage of total rejects represents the ratio of rejected (defective) units to the total number of units produced, expressed as a percentage.

% of Total Reject = (X / total parts) *100

Here X = Total number of Rejected parts

docs.title: 11. Deviation over tolerance
docs.text:
The values which lies above the tolerance or upper tolerance is called Deviation over tolerance.

Deviation over tolerance = USL − Value

docs.title: 12. Deviation under tolerance
docs.text:
The values which lies under the tolerance or lower tolerance is called Deviation under tolerance.

Deviation under tolerance = LSL − Value

docs.title: 13. % of USL Deviation
docs.text:
The percentage of USL (Upper Specification Limit) deviation is used to quantify how much a particular value deviates from a defined upper limit of acceptable values. This can be useful in quality control and process capability analysis.

`% of USL Deviation = ((Number of Values Above USL)/ (total number of values)) * 100`

docs.title: 13. % of LSL Deviation
docs.text:
The percentage of Lower Specification Limit (LSL) deviation quantifies how much a particular observed value deviates from the defined lower limit of acceptable values (LSL) in a process. This is useful in quality control and process capability analysis.

% of LSL Deviation = ((Number of Values Below LSL)/ (total number of values)) * 100

docs.title: 14. Estimated % out of Tolerance
docs.text:
defined as 

((Number of out of tolerance values)/ (total number of values)) *100

docs.title: 15. Estimated % over Tolerance
docs.text:
defined as 

((Number of over tolerance values)/ (total number of values)) *100

docs.title: 17. Estimated % under Tolerance
docs.text:
defined as 

((Number of Under tolerance values)/ (total number of values)) *100

docs.title: 18. Normal Distribution Curve
docs.text:
In order to plot Normal Distribution Curve for X and f(X) the formula is Firstly, enter the given data in the Ascending order and find the f(x) for each data corresponding to it and then finally plot the normal distribution curve.

Here x = Individual value in the data

μ = Arithmetic mean

σ = Standard Deviation

docs.title: XR Chart (X-bar and R Chart)
docs.text:
The XR chart is a pair of control charts used in statistical process control (SPC) to monitor the mean and variability of a process over time.

X-bar Chart (X̄ Chart)

  • Tracks the average (mean) of subgroups of samples

  • Shows how the process average changes over time

R Chart (Range Chart)

  • Tracks the range (difference between highest and lowest values) within subgroups

  • Indicates how process variability changes over time

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Control Limits: Upper and lower bounds that indicate when a process might be out of control

  • Center Line: Represents the overall average of the data

  • Data Points: Each point represents a subgroup of measurements

docs.title: Measurement Distribution Graph
docs.text: Measurement Distribution Graph visualizes the overall spread and frequency of measured values, providing a quick glance at how measurements vary around the mean. The fitted normal distribution curve helps understand the data's dispersion, and the key specification limits (Nominal, USL, LSL) are clearly marked to assess whether the measurements are within acceptable bounds.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Histogram: Gray bars show the frequency (or percentage frequency) of measurements, grouped into bins.

  • Normal distribution curve: The red curve represents a fitted normal distribution based on the mean and standard deviation of the measured values.

  • Nominal, USL, and LSL lines: Horizontal lines marking the nominal value (green), upper specification limit (USL, red), and lower specification limit (LSL, red).

  • Axis labels: Percentage frequency on the x-axis and measured values on the y-axis. Additionally, there's an absolute frequency scale at the top.

docs.title: Measurement Line Graph
docs.text: Measurement Line Graph shows the trend of individual measurements across multiple parts or observations. It highlights whether the measurements stay within the acceptable tolerance limits and tracks how close they are to the nominal value.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Measured values: Blue line and points display measured values across different part numbers.

  • Nominal, Upper, and Lower tolerance lines: The green line represents the nominal value, and red dashed lines indicate the upper and lower tolerance limits.

docs.title: 1. Mean (X-bar) Chart
docs.text:
The X-bar chart monitors the mean of subgroups over time. The UCL and LCL are derived from the average of these means and the process variability.

  • Mean (X-bar):

    X̅ = (Sum of the means of all subgroups) / (Number of subgroups)

  • Upper Control Limit (UCL) for X-bar:

    UCL(X) = X̅ + A₂ × R̅

    Where:

    • X̅ = Average of subgroup means

    • A₂ = Control chart constant (depends on subgroup size)

    • R̅ = Mean range

  • Lower Control Limit (LCL) for X-bar:

    LCL(X) = X̅ - A₂ × R̅

The constant ( A2 ) is found from standard statistical tables based on subgroup size:

Subgroup Size (n) ( A2 ) 2 1.880 3 1.023 4 0.729 5 0.577 6 0.483

Given:

  • X̅ = 10.00

  • R̅ = 0.05333

  • Subgroup size n = 5 (so A₂ = 0.577)

Upper Control Limit (UCL) for X-bar: UCL(X) = X̅ + A₂ × R̅ UCL(X) = 10.00 + 0.577 × 0.05333 = 10.03

Lower Control Limit (LCL) for X-bar: LCL(X) = X̅ - A₂ × R̅ LCL(X) = 10.00 - 0.577 × 0.05333 = 9.97

docs.title: 2. Range (R) Chart
docs.text:
The R chart monitors the variation (range) within your subgroups. The control limits depend on the average range and control chart constants.

  • Mean Range (R-bar):

    R̅ = (Sum of the ranges of all subgroups) / (Number of subgroups)

  • Upper Control Limit (UCL) for R chart:

    UCL(R) = D₄ × R̅

  • Lower Control Limit (LCL) for R chart:

    LCL(R) = D₃ × R̅

If LCL(R) is negative, set it to 0.

The constants ( D3 ) and ( D4 ) depend on subgroup size.

Subgroup Size (n) ( D3 ) ( D4 ) 2 0.000 3.267 3 0.000 2.574 4 0.000 2.282 5 0.076 2.114 6 0.136 2.004

Example:

If R̅ = 0.05333 and subgroup size n = 5:

Upper Control Limit (UCL) for R chart:

UCL(R) = 2.114 × 0.05333 = 0.11277 (rounded to 0.11)

Lower Control Limit (LCL) for R chart:

LCL(R) = 0.076 × 0.05333 = 0.00405 (rounded to 0.00)

docs.title: 3. Process Capability Indices (Cp and Cpk)
docs.text:
These indices measure how well the process is performing relative to the specification limits.

  • Cp (Process Capability Index):
     Cp = (USL - LSL) / (6 × σ)

Where:

  • USL = Upper Specification Limit

  • LSL = Lower Specification Limit

  • σ = Process standard deviation (estimated using R/d₂, where d₂ is a constant depending on subgroup size)

  • Cpk (Process Capability Index):

    Cpk = min [(USL - X̅) / (3 × σ), (X̅ - LSL) / (3 × σ)]

This compares how centered the process is between the specification limits.

  • Constants ( d2 ) for subgroup sizes:
Subgroup Size (n) ( d2 ) 2 1.128 3 1.693 4 2.059 5 2.326 6 2.534

Example:

Given:

  • USL = 10.05

  • LSL = 9.95

  • X̅ = 10.00

  • σ = 0.05333 / 2.326 = 0.02293

Calculate Cp:

Cp = (USL - LSL) / (6 × σ)

Cp = (10.05 - 9.95) / (6 × 0.02293)

Cp = 0.1 / 0.13758 = 0.727

Calculate Cpk:

Cpk = min [(USL - X̅) / (3 × σ), (X̅ - LSL) / (3 × σ)]

Cpk = min [(10.05 - 10.00) / (3 × 0.02293), (10.00 - 9.95) / (3 × 0.02293)]

Cpk = min [0.05 / 0.06879, 0.05 / 0.06879]

Cpk = 0.727

docs.title: Summary of Steps
docs.text:
1. Calculate the Mean (X̅) and Range (R̅).
  2. Use constants ( A2 ), ( D3 ), and ( D4 ) based on your subgroup size.
  3. Calculate the Control Limits for both the X-bar chart and the R chart.
  4. Use process standard deviation ( σ) (estimated using (R̅/ d2 ) to calculate Cp and Cpk.
